comments.body: As I mentioned yesterday and before, I think this is a bad idea. You shouldn’t include an implementation in your API definition. Changing a test name or the CLI of the ledger-api-test-tool shouldn’t be a breaking change to the ledger API version. And even if we don’t break anything, we have multiple versions of the ledger-api-test-tool (one per connect release) which support the same ledger API version (since that will clearly not change every release) which is super confusing.

@gerolf-da what's your view here? I get @cocreature's concerns. Test tool should not be versioned with Ledger API. I could just remove it for now, implicitly saying it's not part of our public API. Or I could add it to a section "Integration Components".

Yes, @cocreature makes a compelling argument. We'll add tests to the tool without wanting to bump the Ledger API.
I like the idea of the "Integration Components" section. The Ledger API Test Tool then has to state which Ledger API Versions it supports.
Introduced the concept of "Integration Components" and moved the test tool there. Also allowed me to include the Integration Kit on that page, which I had missed before.

comments.body: It’s worth pointing out that we do not have a dev version of anything but DAML-LF. For example, `GenMap` is already part of the stable value protobuf but only in DAML-LF dev.
Why do you think that needs pointing out here?

Sorry I didn’t mean to point it out to the docs but point it out to ourselves. This means that LF dev doesn’t mean we can remove things since they are already in the stable value definition. Or we deliberately ignore that until we have a dev-version of values.
@remyhaemmerle-da: could you point us the section in the LF spec where value/transaction versioning is specified please?

+ values are specified in `daml-lf/spec/value.rst`
+ transactions are specified in `daml-lf/spec/transaction.rst`


I called it deprecated as of 2020-10-14 now.

comments.body: If you declare it now stable, it means we cannot remove sandbox persistence until 12 months after the deprecation, right?
That is correct. Though I see our deprecation policy as being on features. Ie I'd see it as legitimate to say "If you want persistence in SDK 2.X, use DAML for Postgres". @cmblitz, do you agree?
I agree with @bame-da's statement.  We are not deprecating a feature, only how we refer to it.
